bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê ôki ayîsiyiniwak êh-mihcêticik , mîkiwâhpah êh-mihcêtihkih , kîtahtawê pêyak awa êh-okimâwit nmoy âwiyah owîkimâkanah . Once upon a time, in a place where there were many people and many tents, one of the chiefs had no wife.
mitonê miyosiw . [He was very good-looking.]
kotak okimâw nîso ayâwêw iskwêwah owîkimâkanah ; êkosi pêyak miyosiw aw ôskinîkiskwêw . Another chief had two wives; one of them was a beautiful young woman.
awa kâ-môsâpêwit okimâw kimotamawêw ôh ôkimâwa owîkimâkaniyiwa ; The chief who was unmarried abducted this wife of the other chief's;
wanihêw awa owîkimâkanah . he could not find his wife.
iyâta-ntonawâci , wanihêw . Although he looked for her, he could not find her.

aw ôkimâw , iyâta-wistah-ntonawâci , âhci kâtêw , ôh ôskinîkiskwêwa êh-kâtât . The other chief, although he too looked for her, merely changed her hiding-place, for he was keeping the young woman in hiding.

têkohtêcih mîkiwâhpah ,
nista namoya nimiskawâw , itwêw . When he came back to the tents, “I, too, cannot find her,” he would say.

piyisk ômis îtêyihtam aw ôkimâw :
âh , nika-ntopayin ; iyahciyiniwak nka-ntonawâwak , itêyihtam ; At last this chief thought, “I shall go on the war-path; I shall look for Blackfoot,” he thought;
ôki kotakak oskinîkiwak kâ-nâpêhkâsocik nka-wîcêwâwak , itêyihtam aw ôkimâw ; “I shall take with me some of these young men who are braves,” thought this chief;

seg.gloss: “I shall go away for a long time; for a year I shall go away.

p.seg: êkosi nka-kîsig-ayâwâw aw îskwêw kâ-kimotiyân , itêyihtam . In this way I shall be able to have the woman I have stolen,” he thought.
piyisk ntomêw oskinîkiwah , ê-wîhtamawât ê-wîh-ntopayit , iyahciyiniwah ê-wîh-ntonawât . At last he called a young man and told him that he was going on the war-path, to look for Blackfoot.

ôhi mâna êh-wîcêwât pêyak oskinîkiwa ,
nikwêmê , êh-itâhkômât , wîhtamawêw . A certain young man with whom he used to go about, whom he called “my brother-in-arms” by way of relationship, to him he told his plan.

hâw , k-ôh-ntopayiyahk , kisîmak âtiht ta-wîhtamawacik âskaw ; namoya ka-mihcêtiyahk , itêw . “Now, I am calling you that you may here and there tell some of your juniors that we are going on the war-path; it is not my plan that we be many,” he told him.
êhag , itwêw . “Yes,” said he.

mâka pitah wâskâhikanihk k-êtohtânânaw , kik-âtâwêyahk môsw-asiniyah êkwah kaskitêw êkwah ayôwinisah , êkâ kit-êsi-nôhtêpayiyahk kêkway , pêyak askiy ka-kakw-âyâyahk , itêw . “But first we shall go to the fort, to buy bullets and powder and clothes, so that we may not run short of anything, as we plan to stay a year,” he told him. LB on {ka-kakw-âyâyahk}: Probably read {ka-kakwê-ayâyahk}.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”

p.seg: wâpahkih ka-mâhiskênânaw , itêw . “Tomorrow we shall go to the trading-post,” he told him.

tâpwê êh-nâ-nipâwiht , ntawâpamêw ôh ôskinîkiskwêwa , ê-ntawi-wîhtamawât ôma êh-itêyihtahk . Accordingly, when all the people were asleep, he went to see that young woman, to tell her of this which he had planned.

tâpwê êh-wâpahk mâhiskamok , êh-atâwêt môsw-asiniyah êkwah kaskitêw , ayôwinisah , minah mihkwêkin , kaskitêwêkin . Then, on the next day, they went to the trading-post and he bought bullets and powder, and clothing, and red flannel cloth and black broadcloth.
êkosi kîwêw . Then he went home.

êh-takosihkik wîkiwâhk , ntomêw okimâw , ômisi êh-itât :
aw , ôkimâtik , wâpahkih pita nka-ntonawâwak mostoswak , tântê ihtâtwâwi , êkota tây-ispiciyêk , itêw otînîmah ; When they arrived at the camp, he called the chiefs, and said to them, “Well now, Chiefs, tomorrow I shall go look for buffalo, so that you may move camp to wherever they are,” he told the chiefs;
niwîh-papâmâcihon , itêw . “I mean to roam about,” he told them.

seg.gloss: “So be it!”
“That is why I have called you.

p.seg: nika-nîsotipiskwân , itêw . I shall stay out two nights,” he told them.
êhag ! itwêwak . “So be it!” they said.

tâpwê , - êh-nîpihk ômah , - kâ-wîh-sipwêhtêt , ê-kâh-kawisimôwiht , wiyâhpitêw nîso otêmah . And so, - this was in summer-time, - when he was ready to set out, when all the people had gone to bed, he saddled two of his horses.

êkosi êh-sipwêhtêt , ê-sipwêhtahât ôh îskwêwah , wâhyaw êh-tohtahât , itêh ta-k-îsi-sipwêhtêt . Then he set out, taking that woman away with him, leading her far off in the direction which he was going to take.

tâpwê wâhyaw êh-ayât , ê-pasâhcâyik , ê-sakâyik , môhkiciwanipêk êh-ayâyik , mostoswah nipahêw pêyak , êkotah êh-nakatât ôh îskwêwah wiyâsah mîna . Then, when he was far away, in a wooded ravine where there was a spring, he killed a buffalo, and there he left that woman with the meat.
hâw osîhtâh kâhkêwakwah , itêw ôh îskwêwah , êh-kîwêt ; “Now then, prepare dried meats,” he told her, as he left for home;
kâya wîhkâc sâkêwê , itêw ; “Do not ever go out into the open,” he told her;
kâya kaskêyihtah ; nka-takosinin , itêw . “And do not feel lonely; I shall come here,” he told her.
êkosi kîwêw . Then he went home.
tâpwê ê-kih-nîso-tipiskâyik , êkosi êh-takosihk mîkiwâhpihk . As he had said, after two nights he arrived in camp.

seg.gloss: “Move your camp this way, toward the north.

p.seg: ôtê wiya k-êtohtêyân nimitâw nama kêkway mostoswak , itêw . Over this way where I have been, toward the south, there are no buffalo,” he told them.
êkosi êh-tipiskâk sipwêhtêwak . Then at nightfall they set out.
nstomitanaw ihtasiwak . They were thirty in number.
mistahi ayôwinisah sipwêhtatâwak . They took much baggage with them.
mîna êh-wâpahk , êh-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik , k-otihtahkik ôh îtah iskwêwah kâ-kîh-nakatât . on the next day, at noon, they came to where he had hidden the woman.
nîpawiw . He stopped in his course.

seg.gloss: “My brother-in-arms, go on ahead.
At yonder hill wait for me.

p.seg: pita oma kâ-sakâk nika-kîskatahên misâskwatwah nîso , t-ôh-kanâcihtâyân nipâskisikan , itwêw . I mean to stop and cut two saskatoon sticks in this grove, to clean my gun,” he said.
êkos ê-âti-sipwêhtêt , ê-pinasiwêt , sakâhk otihtêw ôhi kâ-kîh-kâtât iskwêwa . So off he went, down into the gully, and to the woman he had hidden.
mwêhc êkwah nikaskêyihtê , itwêyiwa . “I was just beginning to feel lonely,” she said.
êkosi êkotah kîskataham misâskwatwa . So then he out the saskatoon sticks there.

seg.gloss: “Over yonder the young men are on the march.”

p.seg: êkos âti-sipwêhtêwak . Then they went off.
ê-sâkêwêcik , kê-wâpamâcik ispatinâhk êh-apiyit , êh-pîhtwâyit . When they came into view, they saw the others there on the hilltop, smoking.

êkwah ôki oskinîkiwak êh-pê-sâkêwêyit êh-wâpamâcik ,
awiyah awa pê-wîcêwêw , itêwak otôkimâmiwâwa . And those young men, when they saw them come forth, “He comes with someone,” they said of their chief.”
âh , iskwêwah miyâmay ! itwêwak . “Why, surely, it is a woman!” they said.
kisiwâk êh-pêy-ayâyit , nisitawêyimêwak ôh îskwêwa . When they had come near, they recognized that woman.
êwakw âwa kayâs ka-wâh-wanihiht itah kâ-miskawât ! itêwak . “It is that person who has been lost for this long time, whom now he has found here!” they said of her.
êh-pê-takohtêyit , awin ôh êwakoni kâ-kîh-wanihimiht ! When they arrived there, yes, it was none other than the woman who had been lost!

seg.gloss: “Truly, you have made a good find in a far-away place, Brother!”

p.seg:
êhag , kêswân nimiskawâw êyak oma kâ-sakâk , êh-itwêt ,
hâ , nikwêmê , tâpwê kimiyopayin ! itêw . “Yes, by chance I found her in this grove,” he said, and, “Ha, Brother, truly, you are fortunate!” he answered him.
êkosi êkwah sipwêhtêwak . Thereupon they went from that place.

itah êh-kapêsicik , ômis îtwêw :
â , nisimitik , êkâ wiya kêkway kit-âtoskâtam aw îskwêw . Where they encamped, he said, “Now, Brothers, this woman is by no means to work at anything.
kiyawâw ka-paminawatawâw aw îskwêw , itêw . It is you who will provide for her,” he told them.
hâ , tâpwê nama wiya tit-âtoskêw ! itwêwak , ôh îskwêwa . “Very well, she shall not do any work!” they said, of this woman.

êkosi miyêw ôma mihkwêkin ,
kaskikwâtah , kit-ôskotâkayin , êh-itêt ,
mîna kit-ôtâsiyin ôma , itêw ôh îskwêwa . Then he gave her that red cloth, saying to her, “Sew it for your skirt and for your leggings.”
êkosi tâpwê ka-kaskikwâtisow aw îskwêw . Accordingly that woman sewed clothes for herself.
tâpwê miywâsiniyiwa otayôwinisa . Truly, excellent were her clothes.
êkosi nistomitanaw pêyakosâp ihtasiwak . So now their number was thirty-one.
tâpwê êh-wâpaniyik , ê-sipwêhtêcik , namoya wâhyaw êy-ihtâcik , mostoswah wâpamêwak . The next day, when they set out, they had not gone far, when they saw some buffalo.

êkosi ,
minahok ! itêw ; Then, “Make a killing!” he told the others;
êkotah ka-nîmâwinihkêyit itêw otôskinîkîma . he told his followers to prepare food there for their journey.
tâpwê minahôwak . They killed some of the game.
êkotah mînah kapêsiwak . Then they pitched camp there.

êh-wâpahk , ê-sipwêhtêcik , kâ-pêhtahk êh-mah-matwêwêyik ; mâka namoya kiskêyihtam tântêh kâ-matwêwêyik . On the next day, as they set out, he heard some shots; but he did not know whence the noise came.
âhci piko êh-pamohtêcik , sîpiy wâpahtamwak . They kept on walking and came to a river.
mostoswah wâpamêwak . They saw some buffalo.

seg.gloss: “When you have killed some, we shall take the meat to the river.
There we shall camp.

seg.q: kik-ôsîhtânânaw nîmâwinah , pêskis êkotah ohci kit-ây-asawâpiyahk ôma kâh-mâh-matwêwêk .
seg.gloss: We shall prepare a store of meat, and at the same time reconnoitre from there as to that shooting.

p.seg: mâskôc ayahciyiniwak , itêw ôhi otôskinîkîmah . Perhaps it was Blackfoot,” he told his followers.
êkosi sipwêhtêwak nîso oskinîkiwak , ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahâcik ôhi mostoswah . Then two young men went off to try to kill some of those buffalo.
tâpwê pâskiswêwak nîswâw ; nîso nipahêwak . They fired twice at them; they killed two.
êkosi êh-wâpamâcik êh-nipahâyit , êkotê itohtêwak . When they saw that the young men had killed them, they went there.

êh-otihtâcik ,
hâw , mitoni kahkiyaw kakwê-otinamohkêk wiyâs . When they got to them, “Now then, try to take every bit of the meat.
ôma sîpîhk kâ-sakâk , êkotah ka-kapêsinânaw , ta-nîmâwinihkêyêk , itwêw ; In that wooded spot by the river we shall camp, and there you will prepare the meat,” he said;

seg.gloss: “We others will go on ahead.”

p.seg: êkosi ôk ôskinîkiwak wiyinihtâkêwak . So then those young men skinned and cut up the carcasses.
êkwah ôki sîpîhk ôki kâ-takohtêcik , êkotah nakîwak , êh-otinakik mistikwah , êy-osîhtâcik wîkiwâwa . And those who went to the river, stopped there and gathered sticks and set up their tents.
nîso osîhtâwak , nîpiyah ohci êh-apahkwêcik wîkiwâwa . They built two, covering them with leaves.
êkwah ôki oskinîkiwak wiyâsah awatâwak . And those young men brought in the meats.

êkwah âsay wâpamikwak kotakah ayîsiyiniwah , ôhi kâ-kîh-pêhtahkik êh-tasinamiyit , êwakoni kâ-wâpamikocik . Now, by this time they had been seen by the other people; those whom they had heard firing, by, them they had been seen.

êh-wâpamikocik ,
iyahciyiniwak ! itêyimikok otôtêmiwâwa . When they were seen by the others, “Blackfoot!” these people, their fellow-tribesmen, thought of them.
êkosi ka-kâsôhtâkwak , wiyawâw êy-osîhtâcik onîmâwiniwâwa . Accordingly the others hid from them, while they prepared their dried meats.
piyisk tipiskâyiw . At last it grow dark.
êkwah ôhi kotakak kâ-mihcêcicik itohtêwak . Then those others, who were many in number, went toward them.
piyis npâwak ôki . At last they went to sleep.
êkwah ôki cîki âsay ayâwak , êh-nipâyit otôtêmiwâwa . By this time these people had come close to where their fellow-tribesmen were sleeping.
piyisk otihtêwak , êh-nipâyit . At last they reached them, as they slept.
namoya nisitawêyimêwak . They did not recognize them.
êkos îsi ôh owîkiyiwa ê-wîhkwêkâpawicik , êh-pâskiswâcik . And so they surrounded their tents and opened fire on them.

êh-pîkiskwêcik , ôki kâ-nipâcik , pêyak kâ-pêhtahk otôtêmiwâwa êh-pîkiskwêyit , kâ-têpwêt ,
niyanân ! êh-itwêt . When they spoke, one of those who were sleeping there, heard that it was their fellow-tribesmen speaking, and shouted, saying, “It is we!” LB on {niyanân!}: Note the exclusive first person plural.
pêyak ê-wîh-wayawiyâmot , otihtinik pêyak , êh-tahkamikot môhkomân ohci . When one of them fled out from a tent, one of the others seized him and stabbed him with a knife.
êkoyikohk kâ-pêhtahkik , kâ-kiskêyihtahkik otôtêmiwâwa êh-pisci-pâskiswâcik . Only then did they hear and learn that by mistake they were firing on their own tribesmen.
ehehehêy hêhê ! kitôtêminawak ! itwêw . “Heavens and earth! Our fellow-tribesmen!” he cried.
êkosi pôyôwak . Then they stopped.
kêkâc kahkiyaw nipahêwak . They had killed nearly all of them.
mitâtaht piko namoya nipahâwak ; mâka kahkiyaw miswâwak . Only ten were not killed; but all were wounded.
êkwah êh-kotawêcik , kâh-nisitawêyimâcik otôtêmiwâwa . Then, when they made a fire, they recognized their fellow-tribesmen.
awa okimâw iskwêwa kâ-wîcêwât , nipahâw ôhi kik îskwêwa kâ-kîh-kwâsihtwâkêt . That chief who had the woman with him, had been killed, together with the woman he had abducted.
ês awa kê-tahkamiht namoya nipiw . The one who had been stabbed did not die.

pîhtokahâw , kwayask êh-pimisimiht ,
mâskôc ta-nipiw , êh-itêyihtamoht . He was taken into a tent and carefully laid down, for, “No doubt he will die,” his people thought.

êkosi ôki kotakak kâ-misohcik ,
nama wiya ta-kîh-nipiwak , êh-itêyimâcik êwakoni ,
ka-sipwêhtahânawak ; ka-kîwânânaw , itwêwak , êh-pakwâtahkik otôtêmiwâwa mihcêt êh-nipahâcik . But as for those others who had been wounded by shots, thinking of them, “They are not likely to die,” they said, “We shall take them away with us; we shall return home,” for they were down-hearted at having killed so many of their tribesmen.

êkosi sêmâk nakatêwak , osâm êh-pakwâtahkik êh-tôtawâcik owâhkomâkaniwâwa , êh-kîwêcik . So immediately they left the slain, too much depressed at what they had done to their fellow-tribesmen, and went home.
êkwah awa kâ-tahkamiht êkotah pimisin pîhcâyihk . The one who had been stabbed lay there within.
niyânan pîhcâyihk êkotah itah kâ-pimisihk êkotah pimisiniyiwa ôh ôskinîkiwah êh-kîh-nipahimiht . Inside there where he lay, lay five of the young men who had been slain.
misawâc wîstah ta-nipiw , êh-itêyimikot , k-ôh-nakatiht . Because they thought of him, “In any case he too will die,” was why he had been abandoned.
piyisk wâpaniyiw , êkota êh-pa-pimisihk . At last dawn came, as he lay there.
piyisk kapê-kîsik pa-pimisin . He lay there all day.
namoya minihkwêw nipiy ; namoya mîcisôw . He drank no water; he did not eat.
mâskôc nîsta nika-nipin , itêyihtam . “No doubt I too shall die,” he thought.

mâka itah kâ-pimisihk , opâskisikan êkotah astêyiw , êkwah pîhcasinânisah , môsasiniyah êh-asiwatêyik , êkwah kaskitêw êh-asiwatêyik . But where he lay, there was his gun, and his ammunition-bags, with bullets in them, and with powder.
piyis kêkâc tipiskâyiw . At last it was almost night.
kîtahtawê kâh-pêhtahk kêkway , êh-pa-pimisihk , êh-matwê-pê-pimohtêyit awiya . Presently he heard something, as he lay there, the sound of someone walking hither.

mâskôc wîstah pêyak apisîs êh-pimâtisit , itêyihtam ,
ôtah kotakihk mîkiwâhpihk , itêyihtam . “Perhaps someone else who has a bit of life left in him,” he thought; “there in the other tent,” he thought.
kâ-pê-paspiskwêyiyit , êh-kitâpamât , pôtih wâkayôsah êh-kitâpamikot . When the other pushed his head into the doorway, and he looked at him, there was a bear looking at him.

êkos êcikây ani kê-nipahit , mayôwês nipiwakih ! itêyihtam . “And so this creature will kill me if I do not die soon enough for him!” he thought. LB: Literally, “he will kill me before I die with relation to him.” Intransitive verbs have a set of forms which related the action (without making transitive) to a third person; the English
piyis pîhtokêyiwa . Finally it came into the tent.

êkotê skwâhtêmihk isi êh-pimisiniyit ôh ôskinîkiwa kâ-wayawîhtahât awa wâkayôs , ôh ôskinîkiwa êh-ntawi-môwât ohpimê , ômis îtêyihtam awa :
nistah nika-môwik ! itêyihtam . When the bear had taken out of the tent the young man who lay nearest the doorway, going off somewhere to eat him, then he thought, “He will eat me too!”
piyis mistahi tipiskâw . At last night came.
namoya kîh-nipâw aw ôskinîkiw . The young man could not sleep.
piyisk wâpaniyiw ; namoya nipâw . Finally day broke; he had not slept.
mitoni êh-kîsikâyik , âsay mîna kâ-pê-takohtêyit ôhi wâkayôsa ; When it was full day, again there came the bear;
âsay mîna pê-paspiskwêyiyiwa , êh-kitâpamikot , wîst êh-kitâpamât . again it stuck its head into the doorway and looked at him, and he, in turn, looked at it.
ayisk namoya kîh-waskawîw , mistah ê-wîsakêyihtahk ôm îtah kâ-tahkamiht . For he could not move, what with the great pain of his knife-wound.
itêh isi êy-isi-sâwahtôt , êkotê nîso pimisiniyiwa oskinîkiwa ; Near his feet lay two young men;
êwakonih mîna pêyak kâ-wayawîtâpêyit ôhih wâkayôsah , aspin mîn êwakoni êh-ntawi-môwâyit . one of these, again, the bear dragged out of the tent, and went away to eat him.

êkos êcik âni kahkiyaw kê-kitamokoyâhk
itêyihtam êwako . “And so it turns out that it will eat us all up!” thought he.
kapê-kîsik pa-pimisin . All day he lay there.
kêyâpic namoya minihkwêw ; mîna namoya mîcisôw wiya . Again he did not drink; and he did not eat.

nama kêkway wâpahtam ta-mîcit ; cikêmâ ôhi kâ-nipahikocik , êwakonik êh-manêsicik mîciwin , kahkiyaw otinamwak ôhi kâ-kîh-nîmâwinihkêyit ; êkosi kâ-kîwêcik wiy êwakonik . He saw nothing to eat; for, indeed, they who had killed them, being in want of food, had taken all the provisions which the others had prepared; and so they had gone home.

êkwah awa aspin kâ-wayawîhtahât oskinîkiwah , piyisk kapê-kîsik nama kêkway wîhkâc môsihtâw awa miswâkan . After that creature had taken that youth out of the tent, the wounded man noticed nothing more all day.

iyikohk êh-tipiskâyik , âsay mîna ka-pê-paspiskwêwiyit wâkayôsa , iyâyaw êh-kitâpamikot mâna , kinwêsk êh-kitâpamikot mâna , kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit . When it was getting dark, again the bear came sticking its head under the door-flap, looking at him eagerly, as before; when, as before, it had looked at him a long time, it came into the tent.
kotakah mîn ôhi oskinîkiwa aspin mîna êh-wayawîhtahâyit , kêyâpic nîso pimisiniyiwa . When, again, it had taken out another of those youths, two still lay there.
âta wiya kêyâpic ôhi nîso ta-môwât , nama mayaw niya ta-môwit ! têyihtam êwakô kapê-tipisk . “I hope he will first eat these two, before he eats me!” he thought all that night.

êh-wâpaniyik , mitoni êh-kîsikâyik , âsay mîna kâ-pê-takohtêyit wâkayôsa , êkwah ôhi itêh kâ-pimisihk ôh ôskinîkiwa êykonih wayawîhtahêyiwa . When day came, and it had grown quite light, again the bear arrived, and that youth who lay there, him it dragged out of the tent.

â , êkwah nêhi kâ-pimisiniyit , otâkosikih êyakoni ta-wayawîhtahêw , êkwah niya wâpahkih kîksêpâ kê-môwit ! itêyihtam , ê-pa-pimisihk . “Yes, now, in the evening, he will take out the one who lies over yonder, and tomorrow morning he will eat me!” he thought, as he lay there.
mâka namoya kakâyâwâtisiw . He had no energy.
êkwah mâskôc ahpôh nôhtaw nika-nipin ! itêyihtam . “But perhaps and as likely, I shall die before then!” he thought.

êkwah mîna nayahtahêw otêma wâkayôsa onîmâwina . Then again he loaded his provisions on the back of the bear, his animal of use.
êkosi êkwah êh-sipwêhtêt , êh-ati-wîcêwât ôhi wâkayôsa . So then he set out, the bear going with him.
êkwah sâsay êkwah miyw-ayâw ôma kâ-kîh-tahkamiht itah . By this time he had recovered from the wound where he had been stabbed.
ayis êwakonih ôhi wâkayôsah êh-wîcihikot , kiyipa k-ôh-miyw-ayât . Of course it was because that bear helped him that he got well so quickly.

êkosi om êkwah kâ-pa-pimohtêcik , kâh-kiyipah nakîw êh-mîcisot ; osâm kinwêsk namoya kîh-mîcisôw . Then, as they thus walked along, every little while he stopped and ate; he had gone too long without food.

êkwah mistah êh-kîh-wîsakêyihtahk , nawac kawâhkatisôw aw ôskinîkiw ; êkwah êh-miyômahcihot , êyak ôhci kâh-kiyipa k-ôh-nôhtêhkatêt . Also, because, he had suffered so much pain, that youth was badly worn down; so now, when he had got well, it caused him to get hungry at frequent intervals.
piyis tâpwê nisto-kîsikâw êh-pimohtêt , âsay namoya ayâw kâhkêwakwah . At last, when he had tramped three days, he had no more dried meats.

piyis wâpamêw êh-wîsakêyihtamiyit wâwikaniyiw ôhi wâkayôsah , osâm mistah ê-kîh-nayôhtamiyit kinwêsk kâhkêwakwah , êkwah wiya mîna ê-kîh-têhtapit kinwês ; ayakô ohci k-ô-wîsakêyihtamiyit wâwikaniyiw . He saw now that the bear was suffering in its back, from having carried so much dried meat for such a long time, and from his having ridden it so long; from all this its back was sore.

êkwah wiya pimiwitâw ôh ôkahkêwakoma , piyis mîna nîso-kîsikâw ê-nayahtahk kâhkêwakwah ; namoya mâka mistahi âta wiyah êkwah kâ-pimiwitât . So then he carried his dried meats; he carried them on his back for two days; but there was not much for him to carry now.
kîtahtawê sîpiy êkwah k-ôtihtahk . Presently he came to a river.
êh-otâkosiniyik , ôma sîpiy êh-sâkêwêt , êkotah ê-sakâyik , êkotah kapêsiw . Towards evening, when he came forth into sight of that river, there in a wooded place, he camped.

êkwah ê-kotawêt , ê-wîh-mîcisot , âsay ês ôma kotakah ayîsiyiniwah êh-wâpamikot ; wiyah namoya wâpamêw . Then, when he made a fire to prepare his meal, some people there saw him; but he did not see them.

êkosi ôma itah kâ-kotawêt , k-ây-apit , mêkwâc êh-mîcisot , kîtahtawê kâ-pasikôyit wâkayôsah , sîpîhk isi itêhkê êh-itâpiyit . So then, when he had built a fire, and was sitting there eating, presently the bear got up and looked in the direction of the river.
wah , kêhcinâ kêkway êh-môsihtât ! itêyihtam . “Why, he must have noticed something!” thought he.
astawînam ôm ôtiskotêm . He extinguished his fire.

ê-kih-âstawiyinahk , kîtahtawê kâ-simaciyit ôhô wâkayôsah , êh-itapiyit tahk êkotê , tâpiskôc kêkway êh-wâpahtamiyit ; piyis pêy-itohtêyiwa itah k-âpit . When he had put it out, presently the bear got up on its hind legs and kept looking over there, as if it saw something; at last it came to where he sat.

tâpiskôc ê-wih-tapasiyit , itêyihtam , êh-kiti-kitâpamikot ôhi wâkayôsah . It seemed to him as if it wanted to flee, the way the bear kept looking at him. LB on {êh-kiti-kitâpamikot}: {-kiti-} is probably my error.
pasikôw , êh-ati-sipwêhtêt . He got up and went from that place.

sêmâk itah êh-pasahcâyik , êkotah at-îtohtêyiwa , mitoni ê-ksiskâhtêyit , tahkih sisonê sakâhk êh-at-itohtêyit . At once the bear made for the gully, walking very fast, keeping always along the edge of the woods.
piyis êh-otihtahk mistah ê-sakâyik , êkotah sêskisiyiwa . At last, when it came to where the woods were dense, it went into the brush.
wistah sêskisiw ; piyis itah êh-kaski-sakâyik , êkotah kâ-nahapiyit . He too went among the trees; finally, where the woods were densest, it sat down.
wîst êkotah nahapiw . He sat down there, too.
kîtahtawê êkotê k-ôhtohtêcik tahki âh-itâpiyiwa ôhi wâkayôsah . Soon the bear began to look repeatedly in the direction whence they had come.
kîtahtawê kâ-pêhtahk êh-matwê-kâ-kîskosîwiht . Presently he heard some people whistling.
miyâmay ayîsiyiniwak ! êy-itêyihtahk , k-âti-samaskisiniyit ôhi wâkayôsah . “Plainly, human beings!” he thought, as the bear lay close to the ground.
tâpiskôc ê-kostâciyit itêyihtam . It seemed to him exactly as if the bear were frightened.
êkotah nipâw piyis . Then he slept there.
iyikohk êh-akwâ-kîsikâyik , êkoyikohk sipwêhtêw . When it was full daylight, then he departed.
nama kêkway âta wiyah wâpahtam . But he saw nothing.
êkosi êkw ê-ati-sipwêhtêt . So then he went on.
êkwah piyis êh-tipiskâyik , kapêsiw sîpîhk . At last, when night came, he camped by the river.
êkwah êkotah êh-nipât , êh-wâpaniyik , êyikohk âsowaham ôma sîpiy . There he slept, and on the next day, crossed the river.
piyisk pihkohôw . He made the far side, in time.
êkwah mitonê êkwah miyw-âyâw . By this time he was very well.
nistwâw êh-nipât , êkoyikohk kotak sîpiy otihtam . After three nights, he reached another river.

êkosi kisiwâk êkwah êkotah wâskahikan êh-ayâyik , wîstâwa êkotah êh-ayâyit , kihci-môhkomâna , wîstâwah êkotah êh-ayâyit , kihci-môhkomâna êh-owîstâwit , osîma êh-onâpêmiyit . Now close by this place was a trading-post, where his brother-in-law lived, an American, for he had an American, his younger sister's husband, as his brother-in-law. LB on {kihci-môhkomâna}: No doubt Coming-Day meant to make him an American as a compliment to me; in the sequel he turns out to be a Frenchman.
êwako ohci , êh-kiskêyihtahk êwako , itah k-ôh-itohtêt , k-ôh-isi-kîwêt . For this reason, because he knew this, he had taken this way toward home.
âsay kîh-pêhtamiyiwa êh-nipahihcik . They had already heard that those people had been killed.

aspin apisîs pimâtisiw ;
mâskôc ta-nipiw , ê-kîh-itiht , itâcimostâmâwa owâhkomâkana . “The last that was seen of him, he was scarcely alive; 'No doubt he will die,' was said of him,” was the story his relatives were told.
mîn ôhi osîma âsay kîh-pêhtamiyiwa . His sister, too, had heard it.

êkwah osîhtâw itah ê-wîh-pôsit , oma sîpiy ê-wîh-âsowahah . So now he made that on which to embark, so as to cross this river. LB on {ê-wîh-pôsit}: Word avoidance: {mihtos} “raft”, freely used in Text 36.

êh-kîsihtât , êkwah êh-pôsit , êkwah êh-pimiskât , êh-âpasâpit , êkoyikohk tâwâyihk sîpîhk êh-ihtât , kâ-pê-pahkopêyit ôhi wâkayôsah . When he had finished it, and embarked, and paddled across, as he looked back, just as he was in the middle of the stream, into the water went the bear.
itah êh-kapât , êkotah cîki kapâyiwa . Close by where he landed, it came ashore.
âsay mâka nama kêkway ayâw ta-mîcit . By this time again he had nothing to eat.
ayis ôhi wâkayôsah mâh-mistahi asamêw ; êkô ohci k-ôh-kitâcik onîmâwiniwâwa . For he had always given the bear much to eat; that was how they had used up their supplies.
êyakô oma kâ-kapâcik êh-ministikôwiyik . That place where they came ashore was an island.
êkosi êkotah tahkohcâyihk namoya wâhyaw k-âyâyit ôhi wîstâwa . And not far from there, at the top of the bank, was where his brother-in-law lived.
êkwah sakâhk êkotah apiw mîn awa wâkayôs . He stayed there in the woods, with the bear.

seg.gloss: “How shall I manage to part from this creature?

p.seg:
mâskôc awa tit-âkâwâtik ôhi kihci-môhkomânah , itêyimêw ,
ta-nôhtê-nipahikot , itêyihtam . Most likely this American will want to eat him,” he thought of the bear; “He will want to kill him,” he thought.
kîtahtawê ômisi k-êtikot , êkwêyâk êh-kitotikot ôhi wâkayôsah , Presently it spoke thus to him, speaking to him only now:

seg.q:
hâ , nikwêmê , ê-kitimâkisiyin , ê-wîh-nipiyin ,
kêhcinâ nika-nipin , êh-itêyihtaman ,
kêhcinâ nka-môwik , êh-itêyimiyin ,
ncawâc nika-kakwê-pimâcihâw , kitêyimitn ,
kitimâkisiw , êh-itêyihtamân .
seg.gloss: “Well, Brother, when you were in misery and were about to die, and 'Surely I shall die,' was your thought, and, 'Surely he will eat me,' was your thought concerning me, then, 'Suppose I try to make him live,' I thought about you, for, 'He is to be pitied,' I thought.

p.seg: pimâtisici , nika-wîkimâw , otôtêma otihtâcih , kitêyimitin , k-êtikot . 'If he lives, I shall stay with him, when he goes to his fellows,' I thought concerning you,” it said to him.

seg.gloss: “Oh, Brother, I cannot do that!
These people, this Frenchman to whom I am going, will kill you.

seg.q: êkwah mîna ntôtêmak otihtakwâwi , kîskwêwak oskinîkiwak ; kika-nipahikwak .
seg.gloss: And when I reach my fellow-tribesmen, the young men are reckless; they will kill you.
It is unlikely that I can bring the young men to respect my wishes; they will kill you.
seg.note: LB: In such a matter, the conduct to be expected of a white man is on a level with that of the most reckless Indian adolescent.

p.seg: namoya kinôhtê-tako-wîcêtin , itêw . I do not want to have you with me when I arrive where the others are,” he told it.
â , namoya , nikwêmê ! ohcitaw kiwîh-papâ-wîcêtin , itik . “Oh, no, Brother! Even so, I want to go about with you,” it answered him.

seg.gloss: “Well, Brother, stay here.
I am going to that Frenchman's.
I am hungry, you see.”

p.seg: niya mîna nnôhtêhkatân , k-êtwêyit . “I too am hungry,” it said.

seg.gloss: “I shall keep that in mind!”
seg.note: LB: This word means that the speaker will conform with the wish you have expressed.

p.seg: êkos âti-pasikôw , ê-nakatât ôhi wâkayôsah , êh-âsowahahk oma apisîs êh-nipîwisiyit ; ministikohk ayisk kâ-nakatât . Then he arose, and left the bear, and crossed the bit of water that lay between; for it was on an island that he left the bear. CHECK -siyit as an inanimate diminutive suffix on 'have water'

ê-kîs-âmaciwêt , kisiwâk ayisk k-âyâyik ôma wâskahikan , êkotah êh-itohtêt , cîk êh-ihtât , kâ-pê-wayawiyit ôhi wêmistikôsiwa . When he had climbed the bank, he went to the house, for it was right by there. When he came near, that Frenchman came out.
êh-wâpamikot , nîpawiyiwa , êh-kitâpamikot . When he saw him, he stood still and looked at him.
piyisk cîk êh-ihtât , mitoni nisitawêyimik . At last, when he had come closer, the other fully recognized him.

kiyipah mîna pê-wayawiyiwa , osîmah asicih êh-pê-nakiskâkot ,
hây hây ! êh-pê-itwêyit osîma , êh-atamiskâkot , wîstâwa osîmah mîna êh-itikot ,
kayâs nipahik otôtêma , kikîh-itikawin , itik wîstâwa . at once he came out again, and he and his sister came to meet him, his sister crying, “Splendid!” as they greeted him, his brother-in-law and his sister both saying this to him. “'Long ago he was killed by his fellow-tribesmen,' they said of you,” his brother-in-law told him.

kiwâpamin ôma ; namoya êh-nipahikawiyân , kâ-wâpamiyin , êh-itikot . “You see me here; since you see me, it cannot be that I have been killed,” he told him. LB on {êh-itikot}: Obvious case of mixing up third person and obviative; narrator should have said {êh-itât}.
hâw , pîhtokêtân , itik . “Come, let us go indoors,” they said to him.
pîhtokêwak . They went into the house.
nipêwin êkotah apiy , itik ; “Sit there on the bedstead,” they told him;
kinêstosin êtokê , itik . “You must be tired,” they told him.

êkos êh-ati-paminawasoyit osîma , ta-miyo-mîcisot , êh-itêyimikot , êkwah wiya êh-âcimostawât wîstâwa ôh iyikohk êh-kwatakihtât , êh-itêyihtahk . Then his sister went on to cook, meaning that he should eat well, while he told his brother-in-law of his sufferings, as they seemed to him.
piyisk mîcisôwak êkwah . Then they ate.

êh-kîsi-mîcisocik , sêmak wâpowayân , pakiwânasâkay , ospwâkanah , ciscêmâsah , kocawâkanisah êh-miyikot wîstâwa ,
omatôwahk namoya ka-kîh-miyitin ; namoya ka-miywêyimâw , êh-itikot ; When, they had eaten, at once his brother-in-law gave him a blanket, a shirt, a pipe, tobacco, and matches, and said to him, “These things here I cannot give you; you would not like them; LB on {omatôwahk}: Gesture to trousers; ordinarily one says {nitâs}: “my trousers”, {mitâs}: “trousers” etc.; but this primarily means the native legging-like breeches, aid in this passage a distinction between the two is desired.
kisîm ta-kaskikwâtam t-ôtâsiyin , itik . your sister will sew something into leggings for you,” he told him.
êhag , itêw . “Very well,” he answered.
êkwah êkotah ay-ayâw , tahkih ê-miyo-mîcisot , tah k-ây-ayât . Then he stayed there, eating good food all the while he was there.

êh-kîkisêpâyâyik , wayawîhtatâw nanâtohk ê-wîhkicisiyit pahkwêsikanah , êh-ntaw-âsamât wâkayôsah , maywês waniskâyit wistâwa . Early in the morning, he took out of the house all kinds of tasty cakes, and went to feed the bear, before his brother-in-law had got up.
pôtih kêyâpic êkotah ayâyiwa . The bear, he found, was still there.
êkwah êh-kîwêt , êh-pîhtokêt , kiyipa waniskâyiwah êkwa wîstâwa . When he went back, as he entered the house, soon his brother-in-law got up.

êh-wâpamikot ,
wa , tâpwê mistahi kitânawêw ! itêyihtamiyiw . When he saw him, “Why, really, he does consume a big amount of food!” was the other's thought.
êkosi kapê-kîsik êkotah ay-ayâw . So then he stayed there all day.
êkoyikohk mîna êh-tipiskâyik ; âsay mîna wiyâkanihk mistahih astâyiwa mîciwin . It grew dark; again the other put a great deal of food into a dish.

niyôhtêhkatêyini , ka-mîcisoyin ; mitoni kisîhkacin , itik wîstâwa ,
osâm mistahih ê-pimohtêyan , êh-itikot . “This is so that you may eat whenever you get hungry; you are too thin,” his brother-in-law said to him, “because you tramped so much,” he told him.
tâpwê êyikohk mîna êh-nipâyit , êkoyikohk wîsta nipâw . So then, when the others went to sleep, he too slept.

kîksêpâ êh-pêkopayit ,
hâ , nka-ntaw-âsamâw , itêyihtam . In the morning, when he awoke, “There, I shall go feed him,” he thought.

âsay mîna sipwêhtêw , êh-ntaw-âsamât , nam êskwa ê-waniskâyit wîstâwa , kêsiskaw mâna ê-ntaw-âsamât . Again he went off to feed the bear; before his brother-in-law had got up, he went, this time as before, to feed it.

iyikohk ê-waniskâyit wîstâwa ,
tâpwê mistahi mîcisôw nîstâw ! When his brother-in-law got up, “Really, my brother-in-law eats a great deal!

seg.gloss: What can he be doing?
Surely he can not eat all that:

p.seg: mahtih nka-kanawêyimâw tânis âwa êh-tôtahk , êy-itêyimât wîstâwa . Suppose I watch him to see what he does,” he thought concerning his brother-in-law.
piyisk kapê-kîsik ay-ayâw . Then he stayed there all day.

iyikohk mîna êh-tipiskâyik ,
ahâw , niwîkimâkan , mahtih mistahih astây êkwah mîciwin , kistês kâ-mîcit mânah . When night had come again, “Now my wife, place a great deal of food for your brother to eat. LB: Literally, “Place in great amount the food which your brother always eats.”

seg.q: mâskôc awa nânitaw êy-itâpacihtât , namoya êkoyikohk ta-kîh-kitât , iyikohk mâna k-âstêyikih .
seg.gloss: It must be that he uses it for something or other; he could not possibly eat up as much as is always at his place.”

p.seg: êhag , itwêw aw iskwêw . “Yes,” said the woman.

tâpwê ê-wîh-kawisimocik , mistiyâkanihk êkotôwihk êkwah astâw mîciwina , êkotah ê-ntawi-pakitinamwât itah mâna kâ-nipâyit ostêsah . Accordingly, when they were about to go to bed, she put food into a huge dish and went and set it down for her brother where he always slept. ed, and then they all got up and went about their day's work.

piyis mistah ê-tipiskâyik , êkwah ê-kawisimocik , namoya wîh-nipâw awa wêmistikôsiw , êh-kanawêyimât wîstâwa . Then, when it was deep night, and they had gone to bed, that Frenchman did not go to sleep, but watched his brother-in-law.
piyisk wâpaniyiw . At last day broke.
kîtahtawê kâ-matwê-wayawiyit wîstâwa . Presently he heard his brother-in-law go out of the house.

êh-tawinahk , wapamonâpiskohk ohci kâ-wâpamât , êh-atimohtêyit , wiyâkan êh-tahkonamiyit , sîpîhk êh-itohtêyit , aspin êh-âkawêwêyit . He opened the door, and with a mirror he saw him, as he went off holding the dish, and made for the river, disappearing round a bend.
tahkih âsawâpamêw . He kept on the lookout for him.
nama mayaw pê-sâkêwêyiwa . It was quite a while before he came back into view.
iyikohk ê-pê-sâkêwêyit , pôtih nama kêkway mîciwin pêtâyiwa , nayêstaw wiyâkan . When he came into view, there, he was bringing no food at all, only the empty bowl.

iyikohk êh-pîhtokêyit , êkoyikoh itohtêw , êkwah ê-kotawêt , êkwah ê-paminawasot , êkwah kahkiyaw waniskâwak , êkw êh-ây-atoskêcik . When the other came in, he went there and built the fire and cooked, and then they all got up and went about their day's work. CHECK heaviness of the reduplicant

piyis ,
mahtih nik-êtohtân . Finally, “Suppose I go there.
tâns âwa tiyôtahk nîstâw ? itêyihtam , êh-itohtêt . What can my brother-in-law be doing?” he thought, and went there.

pôtih sîpiy êh-otihtahk , ati-mitihtêw itah ê-mostâwahkâyik , wistâwa êh-pâ-pimohtêyit , piyis sakâhk . When he came to the river, he followed the other's tracks on the bare sand, where his brother-in-law had walked, and then into the woods.

kîtahtawê k-ôtihtahk itah êsa mâna kâ-sîkihtitâyit ôhi mîciwina , kâ-mâtâhât wâkayôsah . Presently he came to where, evidently, the other had been in the habit of pouring out that food, and there he found the tracks of a bear.
êkos îsi kîwêw awa wêmistikôsiw . So then that Frenchman went back home.
êcik âwa wâkayôsah êh-pê-nâh-ntaw-âsamât ! itêyihtam . “So it is a bear he has always gone off here to feed!” he thought.
êyikohk êh-takohtêt , wîhtamawêw owîkimâkanah . When he got back, he told his wife.

ômis îtêw :
ês âwa mâna mistahi k-âsamat kistês ; ês âwa mâna wâkayôsah êh-ntaw-âsamât . He said to her: “As to this great amount of food you have been giving your brother, it seems he has been going off to feed it to a bear.
nikîh-ntaw-ôtihtên itah mâna k-âsamât ; mâka namoya niwâpamâw wâkayôs , itêw ; I have been down to the place where he feeds it; but I have not seen the bear,” he told her;

hâw , nawac êkwa mistahi astawâhkan wiyâkanihk , ta-kîspoyit wâkayôsah , itêw . “So now, do you put a great deal into the bowl, that the bear may stuff itself,” he told her. LB: Perhaps with ill intent toward the bear.
êhag , itwêw . “Yes,” she answered him.

êkosi aw îskwêw nêo êsinâkwaniyik papakiwânêkin nâh-nîso tipahikan êyikohk miyêw ostêsah . Then that woman gave her elder brother four pieces of cotton cloth, all of the same pattern, of two yards each.
haw , kâ-nâh-ntaw-asamat ôma miyâhkan ôhi , itêw ostêsah ; “Now, give these to him you always go to feed,” she told her elder brother;

seg.gloss: “And give him this to eat.

p.seg: kikîh-wâpamik kîstâw kâ-ntaw-âh-asamat , itêw ostêsah . Your brother-in-law saw you when you went off to feed him,” she told her elder brother.

seg.gloss: “It is because I was unwilling to bring him here.

p.seg: êwako k-ôh-pimâtisiyân , k-ôh-wâpamiyêk , itêw osîma . It is owing to him that I live and that you see me,” he told his sister.
tâpwê ntaw-âsamêw , kâh-tapasiyit . And really, he went to feed it, and, there, it had run away.
êkwah mitihtêw ; itah êkos êh-paskwâyâyik , êkotah miskawêw . Then he tracked it; there where the open country began, there he found it.

ômis itêw :
âh , êyakw âni iskwêyâc êh-pê-asamitân , mîn ôh êh-miyitân . He spoke to it as follows: “Now, this is the last time I am coming to feed you; and I am giving you these things.

seg.gloss: Go away from this place.

p.seg: êkwah kika-nipahik piyisk , êkâ wî-sipwêhtêyini , itêw . He will kill you in the end, if you do not go away,” he told it.

seg.q: â , nikwêmê , kâkikê kisîwâk ohci kika-kanawêyimitn .
seg.gloss: “Now, Brother, for all time to come, from close by I shall be guarding you.

p.seg: ayisk kisâkwêyimon ta-papâ-wîcêtân , itik . “It seems that you are unwilling to have me go about with you,” it told him.

seg.gloss: “Yes.”

p.seg: êkwah kîwêw êkwah wîstâwah wîkiyihk wêmistikôsiwa . Then he went back to his brother-in-law, the Frenchman's house.
êkotah êkwah wâkayôs awa sipwêhtêw . Then the bear went away from there.
êkwah êkotah wîstâwah wâskâhikanihk ayâw , mitonê êh-miyw-ayât . And he stayed there in his brother-in-law's trading-post, and was very well.

êkosi itêw wîstâwa :
nnôhtê-kîwân , itêw . Then he said to his brother-in-law, “I want to go home,” he told him.

seg.gloss: “Very well.”

p.seg: êkosi miyik misatimwa pêyak êkwah aspapiwin . Then the other gave him a horse and a saddle.
êkosi êkwah êh-wâpahk wawêyîw , kahkiyaw kêkway êkwah ayôwinisah êh-miyikot . Then at day-break he got ready, and they gave him all kinds of useful things.
êkosi êkwah sipwêhtêw êkwah , êh-kîwêt . So then he set out, to go home.
nistwâw êh-nipât , êkoyikohk wâpahtam mîkiwahpah . When he had slept three times, he came in sight of the camp.
êkotah êh-takosihk , pôtih ôhtâwiyah okâwiyah êkotah ayâyiwa ; wâpamêw . When he arrived, there were his father and mother; he saw them.
miywêyihtamiyiwa . They were glad.

seg.gloss: “Truly, very glad am I that my son is alive!

p.seg: nipahâw , êh-kîh-itwêhk , kâ-sisikocih-miywêyihtamân êh-wâpamak nikosis ! itik . When it had been said, 'He was killed,' truly it is a joyful surprise to see my son!” he said to him.

kahkiyaw ayîsiyiniwah êh-atâmiskâkot , ê-miywêyihtamiyit êh-pimâtisit , êkosi êkotah ohci êkwah kihtêyihtâkosiw aw oskinîkiw . All the people greeted him and were glad that he was alive, and so, from that time on, they all thought a great deal of this young man.
êkosi tâpwê mwêstas iyikohk êsah kih-okimâwiw . Accordingly it really turned out later that he became a chief.
êkosi êkoyikohk êh-iskwâk êyako âcimowin . And so this is the end of the story.
